metadata.case_name: Rai Sahib Ramdayal Ghasiram Oil Mills v. Respondent Union

facts.text: Rai Sahib Ramdayal Ghasiram Oil Mills closed on September 1, 1952 on the ground that they had sustained heavy losses. The closure was found to be bona fide and the workmen were awarded retrenchment benefit.
The mills reopened on November 14, 1954, though their operations were carried on a reduced scale for avoiding further losses.
Some of the retrenched workmen were reemployed by the Mills but evidently at lower wages than before. The Mills employed some new hands as well.
An industrial dispute raised by the respondent-union because of the non-absorption of 11 workmen.

State Government constituted an Industrial Tribunal consisting of Mr. Kurian under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes Act on May 13, 1955 and referred the dispute: Whether the retrenched workmen referred to in Annexures A, B and C of the Award dated January 1, 1953 are entitled for reinstatement and compensation for unemployment after reopening.

Mr. Kurian retired shortly after constitution. Government of Hyderabad notified on June 2, 1955 constituting a fresh Industrial Tribunal consisting of Shri Bhikaji Patil as sole member in supersession of previous notification.

Previous Industrial Tribunal award dated January 1, 1953 in dispute arising from 1952 closure. Para 24, cl. 6: In the event of the factory being reopened within one year from the date of award becomes enforceable the employers will give first preference to those workmen in Annexures A, B and C... on terms as to basic wage and allowances that were in force on July 29, 1952.

Tribunal ordered: workers from Annexures A, B and C who are not taken back be re-employed and paid salaries and allowances from November 14, 1954 at rates in force at closure, on ground of social justice underlying s.25H and previous award.
Appeal by Mills to Labour Appellate Tribunal, Bombay dismissed.
Writ petition under Arts. 226 and 227 to Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2832 of 1956 summarily dismissed on October 15, 1956.
Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Industrial Tribunal consisting of Mr. Patil had jurisdiction to adjudicate upon the dispute.
Whether the provisions of s. 25H of the Industrial Disputes Act as amended by Act 43 of 1953 were available to the former workmen who had been retrenched before October 24, 1953.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Tribunal as constituted on June 2, 1955 had no jurisdiction to adjudicate upon the dispute because Government constituted a fresh Tribunal under s.7(1) in supersession without making a fresh reference under s.10(1)(c).
The provisions of s.25H were not available to the retrenched workmen retrenched before the amendment came into force.

respondent_arguments.text: After reopening, all former employees entitled to preference over others and re-employment on same wages as at closure, based on previous award.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Para 24 cl.6 of Award dated January 1, 1953

court_reasoning.text: Sub-s.(1) of s.7 empowered Government to constitute Tribunals, but sub-s.(2) of s.8 provided for appointment of another person if sole member ceases. Instead, fresh Tribunal constituted under s.7(1) without reference under s.10(1)(c), so no jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Merely constituting a Tribunal is not enough; specific reference under s.10 required for jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal cannot arrogate powers legislature alone can confer. S.25H deemed in force from October 24, 1953; cannot apply to pre-existing retrenchments. No jurisdiction to apply on social justice grounds ignoring legislative mandate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature did not intend provisions before Oct 24, 1953.

holdings.text: Industrial Tribunal had no jurisdiction as no fresh reference made under s.10(1)(c) after constituting new Tribunal.
S.25H not applicable to workmen retrenched before October 24, 1953; Tribunal cannot apply its principle on social justice grounds.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing constitution of Tribunals, references, re-employment of retrenched workmen

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Amendment) Act, 1953 (Act 43 of 1953)
statutes_cited.relevance: S.25H deemed in force from October 24, 1953; not retrospective

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition to High Court

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; award of Industrial Tribunal quashed on grounds of lack of jurisdiction and non-applicability of s.25H.

key_quotes.text: Without such a reference the Tribunal does not get any jurisdiction to adjudicate upon any dispute.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Wide though the powers of an Industrial Tribunal are while adjudicating upon industrial disputes, it cannot arrogate to itself powers which the legislature alone can confer.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits on Tribunal's power to invoke social justice over statute
